himself he'd never come back here, but he wanted to see it all one last time
before he went to see Akir.

When Blade stepped inside, his heart beat against his chest like a hammer. He
could hardly breathe, and his eyes were tearing up. It was still abandoned, and
it looked like it had never changed. Blood stains still splattered the floor and
wooden pieces were scattered all over.

Blade looked around, crying and just letting his emotions seep out of him. He
walked into their bedroom and remembered when they first put that bed in. Their
first night together on it... Blade whimpered and buried his nose into the fur
sheets, trying to smell Akir's scent again. And for a brief, blissful second, he
thought he did, but it was his imagination.

Everything smelled old and dusty, and their home looked like it was ravaged.
Nothing was what it used to be.

Blade's satchel was still left where he threw it, and he checked to see if there
were still any coins left in it. There weren't any left in the exterior pouch,
but he was unpleasantly surprised to see the decayed remains of the fruit he had
bought a year ago. The golden band that he had bought for Akir was still there,
left in an interior pouch. Scavengers must not have checked through the
foul-smelling, rotting fruit.

Blade grabbed it and held it in his paw, smiling softly as he imagined Akir
wearing the earring. He set it down on the floor in front of him and looked at
the vial, feeling his heart racing in his chest. Blade frowned and sniffed,
uncertain. Was this really the end?

After all of his pain and anguish, would killing himself really free him? What
if the afterlife was real? Would he see Akir there? Was Akir waiting for him?
Blade sniffled and started to sob harder.

He missed Akir so much... He couldn't bear life without his mate. He tried to go
alone and he failed. He came crawling back right to where it all ended, where
his and Akir's life had ended. He wished he could go back to how things were
before, but everything would soon come to an end.

Blade thought about Asha and felt like he was stabbed in the gut. He was a
failure, no matter how he looked at it. His mate died because he couldn't
protect him and he abandoned his daughter because he couldn't control himself.
And Talia... He would be a disappointment to her. She saved him on more than one
occasion, and now he was just going to throw his life away.

Are you waiting for me, Akir? Blade uncorked the cap to the vial and felt
himself shaking. His wings trembled at his sides and his tail swished back and
forth. He thought about Renjee and how he had just left his new friend and
abandoned him too. If Renjee found out Blade was dead... That didn't matter.
Blade would be dead, and he wouldn't have to worry about anything anymore. He
could be with his mate.

"I'm coming, Akir," Blade said softly. He tried to think about the good times he
had with his mate, and a small smile curled his lips while tears continued to
fall. He remembered when they had first met, how Akir saved his life...

Sudden warmth filled him, residing mostly in his chest while it flowed like
water through the rest of his body. It was so calming and nurturing that it felt
like Akir was wrapping him in the warmest of embraces, whispering softly into
his ear and telling him everything was going to be okay.

Blade winced and sighed. He remembered how Akir took such loving care of him. He
nurtured and raised Blade, taught him valuable lessons, and made him who he was
today. Akir devoted his entire life to loving Blade. From the first day he met
Blade to his very last, Akir was there for Blade, protecting him. And even now,
it felt like Akir was still here with him.

Akir didn't want Blade to die. Blade didn't want to die.

Blade cried out and dropped the vial away from him, the glass shattering and
spilling the lethal liquid over the ground. He clutched his stomach and felt
onto his side, crying profusely. Akir didn't want him to die.

Beautiful memories washed over Blade as he sobbed uncontrollably. He remembered
when Akir first said 'I love you' to him as a mate. Old, familiar feelings
welled inside Blade, taking away the pain and agony he had felt for the last
year. He was filled instead with joy. To know that Akir loved him warmed Blade's
heart, and if Akir was truly waiting for him, he would want Blade to live a full
life before coming to see him again.

Akir would want Blade to be happy.

I will wait for you, Blade, and I will be with you every step of the way—until
we see each other again.

Blade lay there for hours, crying and reminiscing about all of his happiest
memories. Most of his pain finally disappeared, leaving him relieved. He stood
up on trembling legs and looked around one last time. He thought about visiting
Talia before he left again and figured that it wouldn't hurt to see his old
friend. He thought about visiting Vespera and Asha too... but he knew he
shouldn't.

Blade found Asha's toy dragon next to her broken crib and felt a twinge of pain.
He wanted so badly to see how Asha had grown and to be a part of her life again,
but Blade was still a danger to her here. If he could just take her with him...
Blade sighed and clenched his teeth. He couldn't do that to Vespera, to take
away her daughter again after they had already bonded. Vespera had a life here,
so she couldn't just leave it behind either.

Blade sighed and started to walk out after grabbing the earring and Asha's toy,
but then something caught his eye. It was a few pieces of paper sticking out of
their old furs. He hadn't noticed those before, and he quickly went to grab
them. He stared at the scribbled runes and sifted through them, but Blade didn't
know how to read. It looked like a letter of sorts, and there was a heart at the
end of it.

Akir... Blade folded the paper neatly and tucked it close to him as he quickly
padded out of the house and took off toward Talia. His wings felt so very sore,
but he winced through the pain and flew as fast as he could. He landed directly
outside of Talia's home and pounded on her door.

Talia opened it and looked very surprised to see Blade. Blade smiled warmly at
her and immediately hugged around her with his wings.

"Blade..." She squeezed him back and invited him inside, quickly shutting the
door behind him. "I've been so worried about you."

Blade nodded and sheepishly pawed at the ground. "It's been... rough," he
stated, not wanting to tell Talia any details. "But I feel... much better. A lot
better."

"I'm glad, Blade. I've missed seeing you around all the time. What has it been,
a year now?"

Blade nodded and chuckled lightly. Talia grinned widely at him and sat down in
her chair while he lay down next to her, handing her the papers. He held Asha's
toy in front of him and set the earring down, smiling softly.

"What's this?" she asked, looking through them.

Blade shrugged his wings. "I was hoping you could read them to me. I... I think
Akir wrote them, but I can't read."

"He never taught you to read?" Talia asked with disbelief. "That foolish sack of
sca—... S-sorry."

Blade grinned, finishing Talia's sentence in his mind. "It's fine. What does it
say?"

He saw Talia briefly skim over it and saw how her eyes softened. "Oh, Blade...
This... This is going to be hard for me to read."

"Is it from Akir?" he asked. His heart thrummed excitedly while his tail swished
behind him. He wanted to know what Akir wrote. He wondered why Akir hadn't shown
him the letters before, but it must have been something he had been waiting for.

She nodded. "To Blade, the love of my life: I'm so sorry. I wanted nothing more
than to be the greatest mate to you, but I failed to keep that promise with you.
I made one too many mistakes, and this time it has cost me my life. Today, I am
going to die.

"I wait here, writing this while you and Asha sleep, worrying and trying to hold
back my fears. I know you'll wake soon, and I hope I can finish writing this
before you do. You've been so worried about me lately, and it warms my heart to
know that you care, and I wish I could have told you—I wish I could have been a
better mate.

I wish I could have told you that today was my last day. Gods, I wish I could
have held you in my arms one last time and cried into your shoulder. I wish I
could have honestly told you everything would be alright. There's so much I wish
I could have done, Blade, but this is the end for me."

Tears poured from Blade. He clenched his paws tightly and buried his face under
a wing, sniffling and sobbing quietly. He could hear Talia's voice cracking and
breaking too while she read, and she sniffled almost as often as he did. But she
held strong and continued:

"I'm going to send you and Asha away so you're safe. I wish I could have
prepared you better for this. I know it's going to be hard, and I wish there was
another way. But I know that if I had said anything, you would be here with me,
and we would both die. I can't bear the thought of you or Asha dying, Blade, and
I'm so sorry that I will no longer be here for you. This is the only way.

"There was a part of my life I kept secret from you, and I'll still spare most
of the details to keep you from doing anything reckless. I was and always have
been a thief; you should know that. But I led a guild of thieves, and I've
stolen so much more than you could imagine. I wanted to build a better future
for our family, and I had been so close to achieving that dream. There has been
a certain group that's wanted me dead for a while, and they didn't find me until
recently. And today is the day they come for me.

"I can do no more for our family, but I have amassed a small fortune to leave
behind for you and Asha. It's enough for you both to live comfortably for the
rest of your lives. Do you remember the first home we ever had—the cave on the
coast? It's buried underneath that wooden toy you had given me when we were
younger—yes, I had kept it!

"I love you, Blade, truly and sincerely; I couldn't have asked for a better
mate. You've made my days warm and happy, and there's nothing more I could have
asked from you. You are perfect, and I hope that maybe one day we'll see each
other again. With all of my heart Blade, I love you. Take care of yourself and
Asha. I will be waiting."

Blade had nearly balled his eyes out by the time Talia had finished. There were
so many memories brought back to life by that letter, and he could practically
hear it all in Akir's voice.

Akir had known that he would die. He sacrificed himself so Blade and Asha would
have better lives without him, and Blade nearly threw that all away.

"Why... Why didn't he try to run? We could have left... We could have been safe
somewhere else..." Blade said, musing over other outcomes.

Talia sniffled and sighed, setting the letter down beside her. "Akir was smart,
Blade. I'm sure he thought about that. He wanted you and Asha to be safe, and
whoever was after him would have probably hunted him down. It's how you feel
about Asha, you know."

Blade nodded in understanding and clenched his talons together tightly. "I wish
he would have told me... but he was right. I would have tried to protect him,
and I would have died with him..." Blade sighed and teared up again. "I loved
him so much."

"I know, Blade," Talia said and stroked the back of his neck gently. "But you're
alive now, and that's all that matters." Her finger traced over one of his
scars. "You've gone through a lot... Why don't you find somewhere to settle down
that's far, far away?"

Blade nodded and stood up, grabbing Asha's toy and the ring. "I have somewhere
already, and someone I should be with. I should have just stayed there, but I'm
glad I didn't. Thank you for reading those to me, Talia. It... It means a lot."

"Of course, Blade," Talia said softly and handed the papers to him. "Take these,
Blade. Even if you can't read, you'll want them." She stood up and hugged around
him again. "Try to learn to read, alright? It's pretty important."

Blade chuckled and nodded, nuzzling her affectionately. "Thanks for being here
for me. I hope I'll see you again."

"I'm getting old, Blade. Just... don't be surprised if I'm not here the next
time you come." Talia looked at him kindly and stroked between his horns.

Blade's expression softened as he nodded. "I understand. Take care, Talia. I'll
miss you."

Talia smiled and opened the door for Blade. "I'll miss you too. Goodbye, Blade."

The door shut behind him, leaving Blade in a slight daze. So much had happened
and he hardly any time to sift through it. He shook his body and fluffed up his
feathers, trying to feel just a little bit more normal again. He took off and
flew towards the coast, quickly coming upon that cave he and Akir lived at long
ago.

It was cold and dank inside, and a lot smaller than what he remembered. He found
the wooden toy gryphon Blade had given Akir. He had found it outside the city
one day, completely abandoned. Blade smiled and moved it to the side as he dug
into the ground. His claws soon scraped a wooden trunk, so Blade dug around it
and was eventually able to lift it up; it was very heavy.

Blade grunted and set it down, opening it to find more shiny things than he
could have ever imagined. Jewels and gold brimmed the very top of it, and then
Blade realized that there was another similar trunk beneath that. His golden
eyes widened as he pawed through some of it, utterly amazed. There was no way he
could carry all of this!

Thankfully, Akir had smartly set aside four different satchels. Blade stuffed
two of them with as much as he could carry and flew back toward the city. His
wings hurt badly, but he couldn't help but to smile. He stopped at Talia's house
again and set one of the satchels down. He knocked loudly on her door and
quickly took off.

He leapt into the sky and flew toward the feral district. He landed for a moment
at Vespera's door and set down the other satchel with Asha's old toy inside,
hoping that it would find its way to his daughter. He deeply wished that he
could tell her how much he loved her and hoped that she would grow up the way he
had imagined. He wished he could give her one big hug and tell her that he was
sorry... But it was best for her to never see him again. At least now he knew
she would have a better life—and Vespera too.

Blade sniffled and took off again after knocking on the door, this time back
toward the coast. He clutched Akir's earring in his paw and thought about
Renjee. He hoped he could return to the gryphon and apologize profusely for
leaving him like that. He hoped that Renjee didn't move on already too. Blade
would have been missing for almost two months by the time he returned.

He stopped back at the cave and filled only one satchel halfway this time and
stuffed Akir's letter and ring inside. He buried the two trunks again, having
hardly made a dent in the first one, and tried to wipe any evidence of him being
here away. If he ever needed money again, he could return here. Then he took off
again and flew west.

Blade sighed, feeling his aching wings struggling to carry him as he flew past
the city. He wouldn't be able to fly as recklessly as before, and it would
probably be longer than a month until he saw Renjee again.

But then he heard a familiar squawk come from above him as a feathered mass
nearly tumbled into Blade. Blade yelped and caught Renjee, straining his wings
even more as he held tightly to him. Renjee was panting and trembling, his wings
drooping listlessly at his sides. Blade flew down to a sand dune and propped the
gryphon up on his haunches.

"Renjee!?" Blade hugged around him tightly with his wings, enveloping the soft
gryphon in a warm embrace.

"O-ohmygosh... You're so... so fast... how... how did you keep flying like...
that... Gods, my wings hurt. Out... of breath..."

Renjee looked completely exhausted. His sunset-colored feathers were all
ruffled, his eyes could hardly stay open, and his wings didn't look like they
could move much more. He swayed back and forth as he sat up, unable to keep his
balance. "You... followed me all the way here?"

Renjee warbled affirmatively and collapsed into Blade's arms. "M-mostly...
Bleeergh, I think I'm going to vomit. O-oh... yup." Renjee broke away for a
moment and heaved away from Blade, making the dragon grimace and turn his nose
away.

"You didn't have to do that..."

Renjee finished and shivered, returning back to Blade's arms. It looked like he
had caught his breath too, but Blade could feel his heart rapidly beating
against him. "I did! I was worried about you. You looked really sad, and I
didn't want to see you sad. But wow, you're a really good flier. I thought I was
good, but jeeze... I don't think I can fly anymore!"

Blade giggled and squeezed Renjee tightly against him. "You'll recover. I... I
brought you something," Blade said and opened up the satchel to take the ring in
his paw. The golden earring rested on a paw pad. "Do you wear earrings?"

Renjee's purple eyes brightened as he looked at it. He nodded and let Blade hook
it through a hole that was already near the base of his left ear. "I used to
wear one before I met you, but I lost it. Thanks, Blade," he said and licked
Blade's nose. "Where'd you get this?" He cocked his head at the satchel Blade
wore.

"It was... a gift for someone very dear to me. I'll uhm... tell you about it
later," Blade said and smiled softly. Renjee did look very handsome, and that
earring complimented his orange colors well. Blade chuckled and set the satchel
down in front of him. "But this is for us!" He opened the flap and showed Renjee
the pile of luxuries inside.

He doubted Renjee had ever seen so much gold before with the way his eyes
widened and feathers puffed out. "Y-you didn't steal this, did you!? That's so
much gold!"

Blade shook his head, but quickly realized that Akir definitely did have a part
in stealing all of this in some way. "No, it was a gift from that same someone
that was very close to me."

"Was he a king!? Wow! We won't ever have to work again," Renjee said happily.
Blade imagined he'd be dancing around if he weren't so tired. "But if he's so
special to you... then why are you coming back with me?" Renjee asked curiously.

Blade pinned his ears back. "He's not with us anymore..."

"Oh, I'm sorry, Blade," Renjee said and nuzzled him back, trying to comfort him.
"He must have been really amazing."

"It's fine. I think I'm finally over it... I feel a lot better," Blade said and
smiled. He looked into Renjee's eyes and felt much calmer than he had before. He
doubted that Renjee could ever replace Akir, but it was a start.

"Why don't we take our time heading back home?" Blade asked and playfully booped
the gryphon. "You need to rest your wings anyway."

Renjee squawked and booped back. "Just not too long! I don't want my friends to
worry about me missing. It's already been a month... Wow, you really do live on
the other coast! I saw the ocean and it looked so blue!"

Blade giggled and started to walk across the sand. Truthfully, he thought he'd
miss feeling it squish beneath his paws, but he looked forward to getting away
from it for a while. Renjee squeaked and followed next to Blade.

"Where are you going?"

Blade shrugged his wings and kept walking. "We have to make time when we can,
right? Besides, I'd like to talk to you about some stuff, and it's hard to talk
when you're flying."

Renjee nodded and looked up at Blade. "What do you want to talk about?"

Blade looked back and smiled warmly. "I'd like to tell you about my life, the
important stuff I've left out... The good and the bad."
